turn.text: That might be correct, but Your Honor, the freedom of association point might be the same even if they did, and this court clearly has never taken that broad an approach.
Moreover--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I think the freedom to associate is not the freedom to have the Government pay for your association.
I think once you get the Government in, paying for the primary, it's a different situation.

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: --That's correct.

Now, in this case, there is no freedom of association claim, really, because if you look at the Republican call for the convention contained in the Joint Appendix, they allow all voters to participate.
The only point they make is that they have some kind of interest in charging the 45.

That may be so, but that interest will only be trenched on by section 5 of the Voting Rights Act if the Department of Justice, the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, or this Court, concludes that that practice of charging the 45 has the purpose or effect of discriminating on the basis of race.
At this point, their claim has to be that they would have the right to make people pay even if that excluded all black voters, or a disproportionate number of black voters.
Again, that is the issue to be determined in preclearance.
They have no First Amendment right that they have identified that would be trenched on by requiring preclearance in this case of this fee.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I assume that a State cannot limit the ballot to labor union members.

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Can a political party limit the ballot to labor union members?
Can you have a labor union political party?

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: That runs a primary election--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, no primary, just as a convention.

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: --And that receives--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They say, you can't get into the convention unless you are a union member.

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: --And receives a place on the ballot above all other parties?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's successful on the first election, and therefore is automatically listed on the ballot in later elections.

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: I don't know, Your Honor.
What I do know in this case is that section 509(B)--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why don't you know?
I don't understand why you... wouldn't the same principle you're announcing to us apply to that as well as to this situation?

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: --I would have to know what the State involvement in that political party's placement on the ballot is, and I don't know what that is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What is it here... you keep saying preferred position--

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --of the Republicans or the Democrats.
Precisely what does that consist of?

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: Under section 24.2 613 of the Virginia Code, political parties receive placement on the ballot above... lexically above all other candidates, and as Mr. Bender referred, there's a function called roll off, which means as you move down the ballot, fewer and fewer people are still voting, and it turns out that being the number 1 candidate or number 2 candidate on a ballot gives you some substantial bump up in the number of votes you receive.
That's the preferential position.

The second preferential aspect is that the parties need not show that this candidate has any particular level of support, whereas any independent candidate, or nonparty candidate running, must both gain a percentage of the registered voters as signatories and have those people spread across the Commonwealth.
I think the number, if you multiply it out right now, is about 15,000 signatures--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could--

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: --so that's more difficult as well.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --I didn't mean to interrupt you.
Were you done?

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: No, that was the end of that.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Would you explain to me the significance of the preferential treatment for purposes of the act?

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
We contend that the Virginia Republican nomination process is pervasively regulated and results in the party receiving preferential treatment.
The pervasive regulation--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay, I'll concede that, but why is that necessary for your case?

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: --It's not necessary to our case.
It buttresses our case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: pamela_s_karlan
turn.label: Ms. Pamela S. Karlan
turn.text: We would... thank you.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Thank you.
The case is submitted.
